goals.question: What is the distribution of salaries across different job categories?
goals.visualization: Box plot of salary vs job category
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of salaries across different job categories and identify any outliers or anomalies.

goals.question: What is the trend of job openings over time?
goals.visualization: Line chart of job openings vs time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any seasonal trends in job openings and if the number of job openings is increasing or decreasing over time.

goals.question: What is the most common job category in the dataset?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of job category vs count
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the most common job category in the dataset and understand the distribution of job categories.

goals.question: What is the distribution of required education level for different job categories?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of job category vs education level
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the education requirements for different job categories and identify any patterns or trends.

goals.question: What is the correlation between years of experience and salary?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of years of experience vs salary
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the relationship between years of experience and salary and identify any outliers or anomalies.

code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['salary'] = pd.to_numeric(data['salary'], errors='coerce')
    chart = sns.boxplot(x='job_category', y='salary', data=data)
    chart.set_xticklabels(chart.get_xticklabels(), rotation=45, horizontalalignment='right')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of salaries across different job categories?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce')
    data = data.sort_values(by='date')
    chart = sns.lineplot(x='date', y='job_openings', data=data)
    chart.set_title('What is the trend of job openings over time?', wrap=True)
    return chart

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['job_category'] = data['job_category'].fillna('Unknown')
    job_category_count = data['job_category'].value_counts().reset_index()
    job_category_count.columns = ['job_category', 'count']
    plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
    sns.barplot(x='job_category', y='count', data=job_category_count, palette='Blues_d')
    plt.title('What is the most common job category in the dataset?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Job Category')
    plt.ylabel('Count')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data.dropna(subset=['education_level'])
    data = data.groupby(['job_category', 'education_level']).size().reset_index(name='counts')
    sns.set(style="whitegrid")
    chart = sns.barplot(x="job_category", y="counts", hue="education_level", data=data)
    plt.title('What is the distribution of required education level for different job categories?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.scatterplot(x='years_of_experience', y='salary', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the correlation between years of experience and salary?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
